org.threadly.test.concurrent
Class TestablePriorityScheduler

java.lang.Object
  org.threadly.test.concurrent.TestablePriorityScheduler
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.concurrent.Executor, LockFactory, PrioritySchedulerInterface, SimpleSchedulerInterface, TestableExecutor
public class TestablePriorityScheduler
extends java.lang.Object
implements PrioritySchedulerInterface, TestableExecutor, LockFactory

Scheduler which is designed to be used during unit testing. Although it actually runs multiple threads, it only has one thread actively executing at a time (thus simulating single threaded). The scheduler uses .awaits() and .sleep()'s to TestableLock's as opportunities to simulate multiple threads. When you call .tick() you progress forward externally scheduled threads, or possibly threads which are sleeping.

Constructor Detail

TestablePriorityScheduler

public TestablePriorityScheduler(PriorityScheduledExecutor scheduler)
Constructs a new TestablePriorityScheduler with the backed thread pool. Because this only simulates threads running in a single threaded way, it must have a sufficiently large thread pool to back that.

Parameters:
scheduler - Scheduler which will be used to execute new threads are necessary

TestablePriorityScheduler

public TestablePriorityScheduler(java.util.concurrent.Executor executor,
                                 TaskPriority defaultPriority)
Constructs a new TestablePriorityScheduler with the backed thread pool. Because this only simulates threads running in a single threaded way, it must have a sufficiently large thread pool to back that.

Parameters:
executor - Executor which will be used to execute new threads are necessary
defaultPriority - Default priority for tasks where it is not provided

submit

public java.util.concurrent.Future<?> submit(java.lang.Runnable task)
Description copied from interface: SimpleSchedulerInterface
Submit a task to run as soon as possible. There is a slight increase in load when using submit over execute. So this should only be used when the future is necessary. The future .get() method will return null once the runnable has completed.

Specified by:
submit in interface SimpleSchedulerInterface
Parameters:
task - runnable to be executed
Returns:
a future to know when the task has completed

tick

public int tick()
This ticks forward one step based off the current time of calling. It runs as many events are ready for the time provided, and will block until all those events have completed (or are waiting or sleeping).

Returns:
qty of steps taken forward. Returns zero if no events to run.

updateTime

protected void updateTime(long currentTime)

tick

public int tick(long currentTime)
This ticks forward one step based off the current time of calling. It runs as many events are ready for the time provided, and will block until all those events have completed (or are waiting or sleeping).

Parameters:
currentTime - time reference for the scheduler to use to look for waiting events
Returns:
qty of steps taken forward. Returns zero if no events to run for provided time.
